Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South10th FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2630tamiment.wagner@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2016-12-01T20:33:33Finding aid is in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Lower East Side Oral History Project
Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring
Bernstein, Rachel Amelia, 1953-
Henry Street Settlement (New York, N.Y.)
Lower East Side Tenement Museum
OH.033
3 Linear Feet in 1 record carton and 10 card catalog drawers
1984-1995 1991-1995 Materials are in English The Lower East Side Oral History Project was undertaken between 1991-1995 to document immigrant life and work on New York City's Lower East Side. Rachel Bernstein, with the New York University Program in Public History, organized collaborations with the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Henry Street Settlement House, and the Workmen's Circle to collect interviews. Topics covered by the interviews include growing up in tenements, family life, ethnic identities, religion, paid and unpaid work, small businesses, union activity, and political activism. Interviews were conducted by NYU graduate students in Bernstein's Oral History and Public History classes. Interviews are generally accompanied by indices and the interviewer's session notes. Many have been transcribed, as well.
Historical/Biographical Note
The Lower East Side Oral History Project was undertaken between 1991-1995 to document immigrant life and work on New York City's Lower East Side. Rachel Bernstein, with the New York University Program in Public History, organized collaborations with the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Henry Street Settlement House, and the Workmen's Circle to collect interviews.
Most of the interviews were conducted by NYU graduate students in Bernstein's Oral History and Public History classes. Additional interviews were done by volunteers from the Workmen's Circle, trained by Bernstein in two daylong seminars organized as part of a collaboration between Workmen's Circle and the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.
Scope and Contents
The collection contains interviews with immigrants and children of immigrants who lived on the Lower East Side, the majority of them from Eastern European Jewish backgrounds. Topics covered by the interviews include growing up in tenements, family life, ethnic identities, religion, paid and unpaid work, small businesses, union activity, and political activism. Interviews are generally accompanied by indices and the interviewer's session notes. Many have been transcribed, as well.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to the fragile nature of the original audio media, master cassettes must be digitized before access by researchers. To request digitization of materials, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
The first group of tapes were donated to the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives by Rachel Bernstein in 1993. Additional tapes were deposited with the library as subsequent phases of the project were completed.
Use Restrictions
Depending on the interview, copyright is held by the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives or the University of Minnesota's Social Welfare History Archives.
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Lower East Side Oral History Project; OH 033; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Access Restrictions
Content of majority of interviews is open for research without restrictions. Contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu for more information.
Existence and Location of Copies
Many of the interviews represented here can also be found in Series 8 of the Henry Street Settlement records (sw0058) at the University of Minnesota's Social Welfare History Archives and at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.
Related Archival Materials
Ordinary People Extraordinary Lives Collection (OH 073)
The Henry Street Settlement records (sw0058) at the University of Minnesota's Social Welfare History Archives also contains interviews from this project. While there is significant overlap between the interviews held by each repository, both hold unique interviews, as well.
Rachel Bernstein was a professor in the Public History program at New York University. The records of this program are housed at the New York University Archives (RG 20.9).
Arrangement
Interviews are arranged alphabetically by narrator's last name in finding aid.
The master cassettes were numbered as each batch was donated to the library. As such, these materials have a roughly chronological arrangement.
Processing Information
Repository received tapes after each phase of the project, and numbers were applied to these tapes. In 2013, a full finding aid was created, in which names were arranged by last name of narrator. As of 2013, some patron-driven digitization of master cassettes has occurred, but the majority of the collection remains untransferred.
